intro: Radiogrammitis clavipila, commonly known as the narrow-leaf moss, is a species of liverwort belonging to the family Pottiaceae. It is characterized by its small, densely packed leaves that are typically narrow and elongated. The plant forms dense, cushion-like mats on rocky substrates, often in moist, shaded environments. Its reproductive structures, known as capsules, are borne on short stalks and release spores when mature. Radiogrammitis clavipila is well adapted to arid conditions, making it a common component of rocky habitats in temperate regions.
